body:
I could reproduce this. The reason that this happens is that `#` starts a comment in `.ini` syntax, so the password gets truncated (ouch!). There seems to be no way to escape those characters, either:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/31921241/boostprogram-options-how-to-support-hash-character-in-a-value#31923154

However - `rpcpassword` is the old way, there is now the `rpcauth` mechanism that stores passwords in hashed format. This is more in line with modern password storage security and could in principle be used to work around this.

However, the script to hash the passwords, `share/rpcauth/rpcauth.py` currently has no way to specify a custom password, it will always generate a random password with 256 bit entropy. Which is more secure in any case... But doesn't help with this specific issue :-)

Have also recreated this. Using bitcoin-qt at https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/commit/57c57df86f14874cfc4b280e04a7f44b19839c26.
bitcoin.conf:
```
server=1
rpcuser=someuser
rpcpassword=some#pass
```
This does not work:
```
curl -u someuser:some#pass -d '{"method": "getblockchaininfo" }' http://127.0.0.1:8332/
```
However this does work:
```
curl -u someuser:some -d '{"method": "getblockchaininfo" }' http://127.0.0.1:8332/
```
Expected output:
```
{"result":{"chain":"main",
"blocks":284781,
"headers":520824,
"bestblockhash":"000000000000000151b374e81b6f3956db0ab62502bd0fa90d461a31200244f2",
"difficulty":2621404453.064615,
"mediantime":1391850295,
"verificationprogress":0.1001564948409792,
"initialblockdownload":true,
"chainwork":"0000000000000000000000000000000000000000000015520d7cd30c40324dc2",
"size_on_disk":17344013534,
"pruned":false,
"softforks":[{"id":"bip34","version":2,"reject":{"status":true}},{"id":"bip66","version":3,"reject":{"status":false}},{"id":"bip65","version":4,"reject":{"status":false}}],"bip9_softforks":{"csv":{"status":"defined","startTime":1462060800,"timeout":1493596800,"since":0},"segwit":{"status":"defined","startTime":1479168000,"timeout":1510704000,"since":0}},
"warnings":"This is a pre-release test build - use at your own risk - do not use for mining or merchant applications"},
"error":null,
"id":null}
```

I've created #13146 to allow hashing a custom password in `rpcauth.py`, so that one can do:
```bash
$ ./rpcauth.py foo '###'
String to be appended to bitcoin.conf:
rpcauth=foo:31aa1353c61d96d89215887fd2d299$3cbfbe3059bd25361eded622079d7948277a42ff18fa8ff3e8b4816d343e2c7f
Your password:
###
$ echo "rpcauth=foo:31aa1353c61d96d89215887fd2d299$3cbfbe3059bd25361eded622079d7948277a42ff18fa8ff3e8b4816d343e2c7f" >> ~/.bitcoin/bitcoin.conf
$ bitcoind -regtest -daemon
$ bitcoin-cli -regtest -rpcuser="foo" -rpcpassword="###" -getinfo
```
Though I think I've now lost track why I wanted a `#` in the password so badly in the first place.

Thanks @laanwj for #13146.
Though, I think silently dropping the post-#-part in non-hashed passphrase seems still something that should be fixed. Not sure how, ... maybe by refusing to run with a such passphrase?
